newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Handelsbanken bid may not go through - paper.
newsitem.headline: Handelsbanken bid may not go through - paper.

text.p: Swedish bank Handelsbanken's prospectus for its proposed buy of mortgage bank Stadshypotek AB may not be sufficiently comprehensive to convince investors about the deal, Swedish daily Dagens Nyheter said on Thursday.

When Skandia AB bid for Stadshypotek, the insurance company had a significantly fuller prospectus in order to convince the shareholders about the advantages, a stock market commentator for the newspaper said.

"Therefore the bank runs the risk of not receiving 90 percent of the shares in Stadshypotek which are required to force remaining shareholders to turn in their shares and complete the deal according to plan," Dagens Nyheter said.
Handelsbanken in December announced a 22.9 billion crown takeover bid for Stadshypotek which is 34 percent state-owned. The bid immediately received government approval.

The deal was announced after rival bidder insurer Skandia proposed to merge with Stadshypotek -- a deal which was opposed by the government. Skandia withdrew the offer after the government embraced Handelsbanken's bid.
Small Stadshypotek shareholders are dissatisfied that agreeing to the deal will mean no dividend for 1996. Analysts had expected a dividend of as much as 10 crowns per share.
Skandia's bid would have allowed Stadshypotek shareholders to keep their dividend, the newspaper said.
